title: Macro Live, FOMC statement and Yellen presser edition

teaser.title: Macro Live, FOMC statement and Yellen presser edition

bodyHTML:
6:45 pm
CG

Greetings Otter -- everyone sit tight, we'll be getting started properly at 1:50pm EST

CG

Wait, nope

CG

It's Fed day, and we are joined by Matt Klein (hi Matt) and total newb member of FT Alphaville!

6:50 pm
MK

This will probably be a lot less suspenseful

CG

Alex Scaggs, say hello

AS

Hi everyone! Matt I can't believe you're not on the edge of your seat about the dots.

6:50 pm
CG

And Rabble, start making yourselves seen as we get moving here

MK

Relative prices of overnight index swaps imply 2.3% chance of a hike today

CG

Alex, he already fell off once before

6:51 pm
AS

I'm next, for sure.

CG

I wouldn't take those odds. Like betting on Cleveland. For anything

CG

Okay, let's talk the Fed

6:52 pm
CG

On days when no concrete decision will be taken, it's pretty much a search for any change in the reaction function, right guys?

MK

Speaking of which

AS

Yep! My favorite out-of-consensus call is that they keep the dots the same for credibility purposes.

6:52 pm
CG

The SAME?!?! Wot!!!!

MK

whoa

MK

Wouldn't that potentially undermine their credibility?

6:53 pm
AS

How so? I think that the last press conference spoke VOLUMES about what their aim was with the last dot-plot cut

CG

Hang on, here's a chart showing the difference between where the Fed and markets are, via some dude named Summers

CG

6:55 pm
CG

Sorry for the size

AS

From Yellen in March:

CG

Point is, market still anticipating dramatically shallower path than the FOMC participants at the mo

6:56 pm
AS

In particular, foreign economic growth now seems likely to be weaker this year than previously expected, and earnings expectations have declined. By themselves, these developments would tend to restrain U.S. economic activity. But those effects have been at least partially offset by downward revisions to market expectations for the federal funds rate that in turn have put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates, including mortgage rates, thereby helping to support spending. For these reasons, I anticipate that the overall fallout for the U.S. economy from global market developments since the start of the year will most likely be limited, although this assessment is subject to considerable uncertainty.

MK

If anyone watching here hasn't checked it out yet, I did a quick review of how the Fed has continued to converge toward the shallower market-implied path of rates and how this path has continued to fall closer to zero http://ftalphavill...-letting-them-win/

AS

Yep! It's all about the market-Fed communication today. Granted, the jobs report probably gave them a decent reason to cut the dots again, but if it weren't for that I'd bet they'd keep them steady.

6:57 pm
MK

This chart shows how tightening expectations for the rest of the year have evolved

MK

CG

So Matt, what does this show exactly?

6:58 pm
CG

(greetings uclallum)

MK

The chart shows, according to OIS pricing, the implied probability that short-term interest rates will be in a given range by the end of 2016

MK

So there is a 50% chance of no hike between now and year end

6:58 pm
MK

and only a 12% chance of 2 hikes

MK

Back in March, the dot plot implied 2 hikes was median expectation of policymakers

CG

seems 50/50 that rates are still the same at the end of this year???

6:59 pm
CG

(hi santi, welcome)

AS

That's changed a lot since the start of the month, for what it's worth

MK

Yep

6:59 pm
CG

guess what's about to happen:

AS

On June 1 the probability implied by futures was 76%

MK

Odds of at least 2 hikes peaked around 75% at the end of 2015

7:00 pm
CG

this next chart will give you a headache

AS

(of at least one hike by the end of the year that is)

CG

https://twitter.com/nanexllc/status/743135854634405888

7:00 pm
CG

And here we go!

MK

http://www.federal...tary/20160615a.htm

CG

obviously rates unchanged, but now begins the parsing

7:00 pm
MK

That's the statement

MK

here are the projections http://www.federal...tary/20160615b.htm

CG

"Market-based measures of inflation compensation declined; most survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations are little changed, on balance, in recent months."

7:01 pm
CG

hi bdbd

MK

Median longer-run rate expectation continues its unyielding descent

CG

yep

7:01 pm
CG

Matt, can you post your chart from earlier showing the 5y/5y

CG

median long run rate specifically dropped from 3.3 to 3%

CG

Doug, in fairness your cat is uncommonly intelligent

7:04 pm
MK

Doug, market expectations have done a heckuva lot better than the Fed and their staff economists...

AS

Median 2016 projected rate is the same! Of course, the range showing the central tendency of 2016 estimates fell. (Score one for the short-term out-of-consensus call being almost right, kind of)

CG

(also what Matt said)

7:05 pm
CG

AS we are dubbing you Alphaville's connoisseur of the out-of-consensus call. The alliteration alone knocks me down.

AS

I'm honored

CG

median and central tendency for the long-run unemployment rate stayed the same at 4.8%, that despite fall in the unemployment rate to 4.7%

7:07 pm
CG

Suggests either they don't buy the latest household survey (an aberration), or believe inflation coming soon. Inclined to believe the former (more labour market slack! yay!)

CG

Here's our man in the Eccles

CG

https://twitter.com/Sam1Fleming/status/743141396350119937

7:08 pm
CG

uclallum, I wouldn't rule it completely out just yet

MK

I have a question: if the policy band is supposed to be 2.25-2.5% at the end of 2018 and the long-run level is supposed to be around 3%, how long do they expect to have to keep raising rates?

CG

TWENTY-FIVE YEARS

7:08 pm
MK

Gradual

CG

no, i don't know, it's a reasonable question

CG

speaking of which, let's look at some other potential questions that could be asked at the presser

7:09 pm
CG

these next few come from tim duy:

CG

1. What's the deal with labor market conditions?

CG

2. Has the effect of QE been underestimated?

7:09 pm
CG

3. Optimal control or no?

CG

4. An Evans Rule for all?

CG

5. Just how much do you care about the rest of the world?

7:10 pm
CG

Regarding labor market conditions, the Fed's own measure has fallen for most of this year, well before the disastrous May jobs report

CG

On the other hand:

AS

The bond market seems to think it's dovish. Bid side of the US 10-year yield's down to 1.59%, via Tradeweb

7:10 pm
CG

: “The Fed’s corrective, however, is also imperfect. The central bank mashed together 19 kinds of labor data, including high-profile stalwarts like the unemployment rate and less familiar esoterica like the Conference Board’s “help-wanted advertising index.” And it tried to clean that data, scrubbing away the noise to reveal the underlying trends. But there is no perfect method for telling the difference, and a recent Goldman Sachs analysis suggests the Fed scrubbed too hard.”

MK

Another potentially interesting thing to notice: inflation and unemployment projections unchanged but future RGDP growth marked down --

worse productivity and lower level of "natural" interest rates

CG

That's Neil Irwin up there

7:11 pm
MK

(that shouldn't have been a block quote)

CG

yeah that doesn't add up

CG

meanwhile, here's how the statement changed from the last time

7:14 pm
CG

https://twitter.com/NickatFP/status/743143914157182976

CG

via the WSJ tracker

CG

slower labor market growth, but economic activity picked up

7:15 pm
CG

referring, I guess, to consumer spending

AS

Somebody's really in the lower for longer camp here (emphasis ours):

AS

7:15 pm
CG

Brainard?

CG

lonely in the lower for way-longer camp since kocherlakota left, I'm guessing

MK

@uclallum, if the Fed did hike in July it would not be expected right now

7:16 pm
MK

OIS implying 83% chance of no hike in July as of this morning

AS

thanks Otter! I must've put "Microsoft Paint doodles" under the skills section of my cv for this job (right, Cardiff?)

AS

But yes it does raise the question of when on earth they expect to get from there to the lowest dot on the longer-run projections

7:17 pm
CG

You think it was your aptitude for analysis and your crisp writing that got you hired?

CG

I mean, that helped, but "Paint doodles" was what got you in the door

AS

It's technical analysis, sort of

7:19 pm
CG

I had the same reaction as Ip here, btw:

CG

https://twitter.com/greg_ip/status/743144871158898688

MK

A cynic might say: "they see what they want to see"

7:19 pm
CG

survey measures following market measures down one of the important recent trends, I thought

MK

Remember when they used to take breakevens very seriously, and then decided not to? Or when they created the Labor Market Conditions Index only to downplay it?

MK

You are correct survey measures show lower average expected inflation

7:20 pm
MK

Mostly due to decline in share of people expecting inflation of more than 5% per year

MK

Someone probably took that to mean the lower aggregate number wasn't a cause for concern

CG

7:22 pm
CG

thanks again to Summers

CG

good point bc, no dissent -- which means even Esther George saw the last jobs report and was like "yeah, no, never mind" (not direct quote)

MK

https://twitter.com/boes_/status/741285742849200128

7:23 pm
CG

right

CG

still

MK

The movement in the blue vs yellow lines explains why overall number down

7:24 pm
CG

would make for a good question

CG

during the presser

CG

(about 5 minutes away)

7:24 pm
CG

http://www.ustream.tv/federalreserve

CG

that's where you'll be able to watch

MK

Yeah it's not clear to me why we should underweight the expectations of certain people when counting up the overall number

7:27 pm
CG

Right. The nation's average IQ would be higher/lower if we excluded all the idiots/geniuses

CG

This in the statement is a pretty good mid-year summary of the real economy to date:

CG

Although the unemployment rate has declined, job gains have diminished. Growth in household spending has strengthened.

7:27 pm
CG

Since the beginning of the year, the housing sector has continued to improve and the drag from net exports appears to have lessened, but business fixed investment has been soft.

AS

Strategists at TD Securities say we should expect some Brexit questions in the presser

CG

hell yes!

7:28 pm
AS

Interesting because we've got that (could be an issue in July)

AS

then the U.S. presidential election (could be an issue in September)

CG

which she will totally respond with some version of "monitoring closely"

7:28 pm
CG

Two minutes!

MK

The bit about net exports is interesting. Brad Setser said he was surprised about how well they've held up here given supposed strength of domestic expansion and the earlier moves in the dollar: http://blogs.cfr.o...ss-of-u-s-imports/

MK

It's due to weak growth in non-energy imports

7:29 pm
MK

Not really a bullish signal when combined with the weakness in domestic goods production

CG

And he hesitantly said he wouldn't be surprised if they imposed a bigger drag in coming months or quarters, I believe

CG

wait, here's a better link: http://www.federal...live-broadcast.htm

7:30 pm
CG

And we are off

CG

https://twitter.com/pdacosta/status/743148766367125508

MK

"recent economic indicators have been mixed...cautious approach remains appropriate"

7:32 pm
MK

If you want proof the Fed really is data-dependent, the moves in the dots since the first hike are a good place to start

MK

"fortunately, 1st quarter slowdown in HH spending appear to have been temporary"

CG

Aaaaaaand hello and welcome to Game 6 of the NBA finals!...

7:33 pm
MK

vehicle sales growth has slowed down a lot, fwiw https://research.s...d2/series/ALTSALES

MK

"important not overreact to one or two monthly readings"

MK

(about job market)

7:34 pm
CG

indeed

AS

she almost sounded optimistic about wage growth

CG

"measures of inflation compensation" DRINK

7:36 pm
MK

Yellen now discounting breakeven inflation rates as a measure of inflation expectations

CG

right

CG

Didn't say much about global trends in that intro, suspect will play a big role in teh questions

7:38 pm
CG

expecting UR to stay below long run rate for next few years

MK

Now she's explaining the projections. RGDP growth is projected to be a bit less than what was previously forecast. Unemployment and inflation unchanged, which implies worse productivity. Presumably this (and the implication for rates) will come up in the questions.

MK

"vulnerabilities in the global economy remain"

7:40 pm
MK

"perceptions of, and appetite for risk can change abruptly"

MK

"headwinds" -- DRINK

CG

Astounding that the estimate for the natural rate of unemployment, now at 4.8%, was 5.6% just a few years ago:

7:41 pm
CG

MK

Reminder Yellen wanted to hike rates in 1996/7 because the unemployment rate was below 5.5% and she thought that was the NAIRU

AS

once again Yellen's reminding everyone that the dots are just projections, not a plan

7:43 pm
MK

Questions starting

MK

Sam Fleming up first

AS

Brexit question!

7:43 pm
CG

FLEMING

CG

SAM I AM FLEMING

MK

"fair to say it was one of the factors that factored into today's decision"

7:44 pm
MK

THANKS A LOT BRITS

CG

Huh, much clearer statement on this than I'd expected.

CG

a solid yes, it freaking matters

7:44 pm
CG

shorter: WTF are you guys doing over there

MK

In 1927 the Fed adopted an unreasonably easy monetary policy to help UK maintain peg to gold

MK

(This is probably not the equivalent)

7:45 pm
MK

Steve Liesman asking why rate outlook keeps going down and RDGP outlook isn't changing

CG

decent Q

MK

"Why does the Fed have to keep lowering rates to get the same outcome?"

7:45 pm
CG

bandit8

MK

Answer is basically that the "neutral" rate keeps going down

MK

Mix of "headwinds" plus other things they don't fully understand (productivity?)

7:48 pm
AS

Yep, productivity, she says

AS

And "we have aging societies in many parts of the world that could depress this neutral rate"

MK

That puts her on Team Shirakawa rather than Team Goodhart

7:49 pm
MK

(Yellen's statement about aging and neutral rate)

CG

yes

CG

depress nat-rate, downward secular pressure on inflation

7:53 pm
MK

Next question about the Labor Market Conditions Index and whether the decline can be blamed on December hike

CG

good Q there: labor market conditions down

MK

"experimental research product"

7:54 pm
CG

IS IT ALL YOUR FAULT

CG

state of the labor market is still healthy, but loss of momentum

MK

"the state of the labor market is still healthy...loss of momentum"

7:54 pm
CG

calling something "experimental" is a polite way to throw shade

MK

To be clear, it was her experiment

CG

decent strength in labor market based on other measures

7:56 pm
AS

Here's what's happened to that Labor Market Conditions Index since the rate hike:

AS

MK

"I don't think a single rate increase of 25 bps in December has much significance for the outlook"

7:56 pm
CG

actual lol just now

CG

nice chart

MK

Hilsentrath up now

7:57 pm
MK

question is why rates are low

MK

"Mkt expectations of path of short-term rates" plus "term premium"

MK

Yes it would have to be some combination of those two things

7:59 pm
CG

by definition there's nothing else left

MK

ECB and BOJ are doing bond-buying, maybe pushing down "term premiums", Yellen says

MK

"We're quite uncertain where rates are heading in the longer-term"

8:00 pm
MK

Policymakers: they're just like us

AS

So term premia are SUPER SUPER LOW. (My very scientific analysis)

AS

The 10-year TP hit -0.5 earlier this month

8:01 pm
AS

And before this month, it had only been lower four times. All of those times were in 1962.

CG

This interpretation started under Bernanke: 1) Asset purchases afffect term premium more directly, which also matters more for financial stability, 2) forward guidance and language generally affects expectations of path of short rates, less distortionary for finstability

MK

Next question: "What do you need to see to convince you labor market is still moving toward full employment?"

8:02 pm
MK

(I'd note there is no way to actually measure the "term premium", just different models for estimating it by attempting to separate out genuine expecations for future short rates from longer-term yields)

CG

labor market slack debate about three years old now, still no resolution

AS

Ah right, thanks Matt - that was according to the NY Fed ACM model for term premium

8:03 pm
MK

Yellen's answer is "no formula"

AS

"every meeting is live" DRINK

MK

"no meeting is off the table"

8:03 pm
CG

crossing fingers that someone will ask a plumbing question

CG

what'll be the new policy rate?!?!

AS

YES please. I'd love to know which rate she favors

8:04 pm
MK

next question about election

MK

"we are very focused on assessing the economic outlook without taking politics into account"

CG

yeah this is one she won't wanna touch

8:06 pm
MK

@Mari and @bcinthedistrict that's why she said no formula, expected trend to slow down as job market recovers

CG

question about inflation expectations vs actual inflation

CG

which she weights more

8:07 pm
MK

"Inflation is as low as it's been because of oil and the dollar" those things won't keep going down/up so therefore inflation should rebound towards underlying trend

MK

"I'm always careful to call it inflation compensation rather than inflation expectations"

MK

There's a risk premium and an expectation bundled together

8:09 pm
CG

Cites the effect of the inflation risk premium

CG

yes

AS

Interesting, almost sounds like she's discounting surveys of individuals (which have moved down) vs forecasters (which have been steady)

8:09 pm
AS

For inflation expectations, that is

MK

My question: if actual inflation is behaving more or less as they expected, why were they ok with a policy path where it took so many years for inflation to rise back to target?

CG

minutes don't get corrected to reflect how the world goes to hell in the three weeks since the meeting

8:10 pm
CG

basically

CG

jacobin, fomc members don't help themselves by dropping calendar dates so frequently in their speeches

MK

@bcinthedistrict yes that's also a good question: how do they reconcile forecast for very long time for inflation to get back to target against "transitory" nature of "headwinds" + close proximity to NAIRU?

8:14 pm
AS

@Jacob, for more fun reading on Fed communication (and why tying to calendar dates is seen as a bad idea) -- https://research.c...gm/usmpf/2016.aspx

CG

defending central bank independence to prevent the govt ordering the CB to print money

MK

"Fiscal policy can be a very important tool"

8:16 pm
MK

Helicopter money is "something academics are debating...very abnormal, extreme situation"

MK

Question is whether the Fed goes "cashflow negative"

MK

basically if rates they pay on their reserves exceed what they earn on their assets

8:17 pm
CG

right

AS

For a second there I thought she was asking about whether negative rates are in the toolbox (no such luck)

MK

"basically if this happens the economy would be doing very well"

8:18 pm
MK

you'd have to have much higher short-term rates than now

MK

especially since a big chunk of the liability side is cash

MK

Question is about policy divergence and spillovers

8:20 pm
MK

"tends to affect exchange rates...standard part of how monetary policy works. Stronger dollar has a depressing effect"

MK

Foreign developments are "relevant" for US monetary policy but "not a constraint"

CG

Yellen all but saying I WISH I had the problems y'all are talking about

8:22 pm
MK

Next question: oil

CG

i always feel a little bad for the reporters at the end. All the good questions are already taken

AS

https://twitter.com/marthastewart/status/326365867111772160

8:23 pm
MK

"It takes falling oil prices to have an impact on inflation. If they stop falling then impact on inflation stops. Now prices are going back up"

MK

In retrospect, that tweet was a good time to call the top

MK

gains of $1400 per US household because of cheaper oil

8:24 pm
CG

was her very next tweet "paprika"?

CG

AAAAAAAND we are done!

MK

actually I stand corrected, there was a rally from end of April through mid-September

8:24 pm
CG

depressing slow music now playing

MK

the music fits with the outlook as expressed in the SEP

CG

The Martha Indicator gets squashed before it really had a chance

8:25 pm
CG

anyways

CG

let's wrap this up like a tortilla

CG

or whatever

8:25 pm
CG

takeaways!

CG

who's got one?

AS

Lots of talk about how important global factors are for Fed policy today -- Brexit, negative rates in Europe & Japan

8:26 pm
CG

I'm still surprised by how clear and forceful she was on Brexit

AS

And the impact of what the ECB & BOJ are doing on their policy-making decisions

MK

Likewise

8:27 pm
CG

Global factors are bigger deal, and of course the Fed keeps drifting ever casually towards markets rather than the other way around

CG

no dissent this time, i suspect there will be more unanimity in this meeting's minutes, if only because the need to punt was more obvious

CG

which doesn't mean the squabbling won't return

8:30 pm
CG

Anyways, we are done here folks

MK

I don't think we've gotten much new information since the last press conference about how they think. They continue to be uncertain about the outlook, sensitive to a range of data, unwilling to reveal a straightforward reaction function for their policy, disinclined to treat any individual indicator with too much weight, and big on nuance. The main surprise is the extent to which the shorter-term policy hasn't changed even as the longer-term rate forecast has come down significantly.

CG

Well said, and an excellent place to close it down

8:34 pm
CG

Rabblers, thanks for hanging out with us

CG

And for going easy on Alex her first time Live-ing

CG

You've gotten more polite through the years. Well done everyone. Paul and Bryce are back tomorrow at the usual time.

8:34 pm
CG

So long!

CG

sounded confident about household spending
originalTitle: Macro Live, FOMC statement and Yellen presser edition
